physDesc.p: This letter consists of three pages typed on carbon paper, followed by one Certificate of Issue and one Sales Report. The top left corner of the first page contains an address header for Aldington. The top right corner of the first page is torn off. The top right on each page after the first has a heading (Mr. Aldington - [Page #]), and each page has the date line underneath this. The first page date line is preceded by a "/ 46."

div.p: Your letter of March 4th came to-day, an uncommonly quick journey. The mails are evidently beginning to be natural again. I was delighted to get it; you are the most satisfactory correspondent I have.

In the first place, I cannot understand how my secretary omitted to put in the little slip about the Imagist royalties that still come in, although we are letting the volumes go out of print. I enclose it in this letter, and you will therefore see what the cheque for 2-7-4 was for. The difference is exchange.

I got the February number of the “Anglo-French Review” all right the other day, and also a guinea from the editor, so that is very satisfactory. They published a poem called “One! Two! Three!” The other poem which they have is called “Summer Night Piece.” In my book where I keep a list of poems and articles accepted, I find three other poems listed as having been sent to you: “Granadilla,” “Carrefour,” and “Paradox.” Probably one of these was omitted in the enclosure and you only had two of them. When “Coterie” published the two poems, I shall simply consider the third as never having gone to you, and everything is all right and perfectly satisfactory.

I am going to New York in June to give the Phi Beta Kappa poem at Columbia University Commencement, and I will go to see the “Dial” people then and mention your claim. They are perfectly honest and nice young fellows, and I have no doubt they will pay you promptly unless Johnson left no record of his debt to you. The “Dial” is a good paper since they took it up, although a little futuristic for my taste, but Johnson is an improvident goose, and he is well out of it, and the “Dial” well out of him.

I do not know what is the matter with Fletcher. He is behaving like a perfect cad. He has written me a most abominable letter to-day in which he does not in the least approve of for the very silly reason that he cannot do it himself. As a matter of fact, my illness was a hernia got from lifting the hind wheels of a carriage to obviate a runaway some years ago. I obviated the runaway, but have been suffering from it ever since and this is the second operation I have had to undergo in consequence. It is not an illness but an accident, just as if I might have been shot on a battlefield. It has laid me out, naturally, but I hope to be all right before long, barring the shock of the operation which has been very great, and which has not been helped by the death of Mrs. Russell's youngest grandchild and the severe illness of her daughter which happened two weeks after my operation. Mrs. Russell had to leave me, and I have been along and under great anxiety. The daughter is now out of danger I am happy to say, and I hope to get Mrs. Russell back shortly.

Fletcher evidently has no intention of asking me to contribute to his American number of the “Chap Book.” I need hardly explain to you how abominable this is, not only from the point of view of my position here in America, but from the point of view of Fletcher's own constantly expressed admiration of my work. He is a perfect chameleon and takes the colour of whoever he is with, but I think he has been written to a great deal by Aiken, and has probably been seeing T.S. Eliot and others of the hostile faction.

It is pretty discouraging to see how many of the poets are underbred when you know them well. If he had no wanted my work, a nice man would have written and told me so, and not sneaked and pretended he was not doing
the thing. It makes one sick how few of the present generation of poets have the instincts of gentlemen. It is not true of France, so far as I have had anything to do with the poets there, and it is not true of the poets of any other period in the history of English literature. If this is a result of democracy, I am for aristocracy pure and simple. I have helped Fletcher a great deal, and I am broken hearted at his attitude and his abominable behavior.
I cannot write much more to-day as I am all in.
